summary:
Addiction Medicine physician and Department Lead in EDI & Social Accountability at Sunnybrook Hospital. I lead the development of the Financial Literacy Curriculum and I'm on the Financial Aid Committee at UofT Faculty of Medicine. My academic interests are in socioeconomic inequities in accessing education, student financial education & career planning, and mentorship of equity-deserving groups. 
Twitter: @stephanieyzhou
Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/c/BreakingBadDebt
fullName: Stephanie Y. Zhou, MD, MSc, CCFP

ingestedContentSummary.description: In this video, I interview lawyer Noa Weingarten to discuss the pros and cons of getting a prenuptial agreement and cohabitation agreement. We provide an overview of the terminology and discuss cases when it comes to prenups and cohabitation...
ingestedContentSummary.title: Getting a Prenup: Overview of Marriage Contracts & Cohabitation Agreements (Part 1)

message.text:
One of the most commonly asked questions I get asked by trainees is 'Should I get a prenup or cohabitation agreement?' - Getting married or choosing to move in together is one of the biggest financial decisions you'll make and it's important to know your rights and obligations. In this video, I collaborate with lawyer Noa Weingarten to develop an overview of #prenups and #cohabitationagreements, the terminology and case study. This is part 1 of a 2 part series. 
Link to watch the video: https://lnkd.in/giG6c9_f

ingestedContentSummary.description: The Our Health, Our City Implementation Panel is now accepting applications. People with lived, living or professional experience are encouraged to apply by April 17, 2024. More information below. Apply Now A Mental Health, Substance Use, Harm...
ingestedContentSummary.fullText: The Our Health, Our City Implementation Panel will provide advice to support the the implementation of the Our Health, Our City strategy. The panel consists of a total of 18 members, including: All panel members must be committed to fulfilling the vision and mission of Our Health, Our City and have a proven track record of contributing to substance use and/or mental health programming, policy development or community engagement, as well as advancing equity, diversity, inclusion and accessibility. The length of panel membership will be for two-and-a-half years. The Implementation Panel will meet approximately once every two months for up to two hours in person. The option to attend the meeting virtually will be available. Those who identify as having lived or living experience will be paid a $50 stipend per meeting attended. Accommodations will be made to support members of the panel, as requested. This application is your opportunity to share why you are a strong candidate to join the Our Health, Our City Implementation Panel.   To apply, please complete the online form by April 17, 2024 at 11:59 p.m. Eastern Time. Applications will be reviewed and nominated for consideration by the Board of Health. All applicants will be notified by email on the status of their application. If you need help with your application or would prefer to apply by phone, please contact Toronto Public Health at 416-338-7600 and ask to speak to a member of the Mental Health, Substance Use, Harm Reduction and Treatment Strategy Team.
ingestedContentSummary.title: Our Health, Our City

message.text:
The City of Toronto and Board of Health is seeking applicants to the Our Health, Our City Implementation Panel. Members of this panel will provide advice to support the implementation of Our Health, Our City: A Mental Health, Substance Use, Harm Reduction and Treatment Strategy for Toronto. This strategy is a comprehensive five-year plan to reduce substance use related harms and promote mental health, well-being and safety for all Torontonians.

Individuals with lived/living experience, community agency leadership, health care providers, and researchers in #mentalhealth, #substanceuse, or #harmreduction are encouraged to apply at the link below: https://lnkd.in/gWVTbcPW

Great to moderate today morning's session at Ontario College of Family Physicians on Managing #Anxiety with Drs. Sharon Bal, Mehry Kianfar, and Mel Borins. Lots of questions from family doctors who are overwhelmed with managing increasing cases of anxiety in their patient populations. Thanks to our panelists for sharing some great tools from Centre for Effective Practice and tips from their own practice.

I'm honoured to have been selected as one of The Peak's Emerging Leaders for 2024 in the #Healthcare category for my work in addiction medicine at Sunnybrook and teaching at Temerty Faculty of Medicine, University of Toronto.
The Peak’s annual list celebrates up-and-coming young leaders shaping Canada's economy, culture, and society. The 2024 Emerging Leaders are ambitious Canadian leaders under forty who go above and beyond their roles to make a change.
Check out the full list of other inspiring leaders: https://lnkd.in/g2qugBSE

ingestedContentSummary.description: My keynote on International Women's Day for Queen's University alumni, taking place at the Smith School of Business in Toronto. I talk about my upbringing as an immigrant, helping my family navigate a new country and my early introduction to financial...
ingestedContentSummary.title: A Prescription for Powerful Women | Keynote at Queen's University #InternationalWomensDay

message.text:
I'm sharing the recording of my keynote at Queen's University on #internationalwomensday at Smith School of Business at Queen's University in Toronto. I speak about my upbringing as an immigrant, helping my family navigate a new country, women's health challenges, my early introduction to #financialliteracy and how that is important for women to achieve financial independence.
A change from the usual hour-long lectures I give...let me know what you think!

#healthiswealth #ElevateHer
https://lnkd.in/diVGY2k3

Today started at 5am at the hospital, my mom was going into surgery for cancer and I was there to translate and navigate the pre-operative process with her. After a year of various appointments, labs, scans...she was finally getting surgery.

As she was heading into the OR, I rushed myself to a keynote I was giving Queen's University / Smith School of Business at Queen's University for International Women's Day for 7:30am before heading back to the hospital.

Today flew by so quickly and it made me reflect on the value of time. They say 'you can't buy time', but over the past year of supporting my mom - I realize you can if you make a conscious decision to.

When I was a student away at university, I only saw my parents during the holidays b/c it was expensive to frequently go back home.

Then in med school and residency (now 6 figures in debt), I would often work 6am-7pm, on weekends, doing 24-hour on call shifts....and if I was lucky I could see my parents once a month.

Each time I saw them, they looked significantly older, thinner and with more white hair than the last time...

As an attending, with my debts paid off, I prioritized financial independence, broadening my income streams so I wasn't working so much all the time. I cut my clinical work down from 6 days a week to 3 days. I was glad I put my wellness first, b/c that's when my mom was diagnosed with cancer. Except this time, I had a lot more time to take care of her.

I realized early that if I kept working the way I did, I would retire with a lot more money but not my health nor family around to enjoy those earnings with. Life is short, and disease or disability can happen earlier than you think. The earlier I prioritized my financial wellness, the more time I bought for myself to enjoy my healthy years with loved ones. #internationalwomensday   #financialindependence

commentary.text: For Part 2 of the series: https://youtu.be/JRb_jFp_uHs
Thank you for sharing & supporting the work that I do and a special mention also to Jahanzaib Ansari for the nomination!
Thank you for the award and for supporting young leaders in the Pan-Asian community. It was truly a pleasure to meet all the Ascend volunteers who took the time to organize this event.
Great work in supporting Family Medicine!!

Don't be afraid of getting rejected for leadership roles. By applying to roles you are interested in and interviewing, it puts your name out there to the hiring committee. Usually the people involved in hiring for one role are often involved in hiring for other roles as well. Should the person who got the job leave or should a different role that matches your interests open up, now the hiring committee knows who you are and that you are interested in a promotion.

Having a social media presence is important to communicate what you are working on to the broader audience. Your department chief may not always be proactive in asking you what project you have been working on, but if they are on Twitter/X, LinkedIn or ResearchGate, this is one indirect way for you to share with them your accomplishments.

Find mentors in the space who have gone through the promotions process. People get promoted for different streams - is it due to research, teaching or creative professional activity? Identifying mentors who have similar areas of interest and have been successful will help you identify what you should put forward to the promotions committee and areas to improve on. In my experience, when I was initially told I wasn't eligible to apply for early promotion, I found a mentor who had done the same Masters program as I did, who was promoted. They helped advocate for me to become eligible to apply for the promotion.
Amazing work - it's great to see your brand take social accountability and giving back into account!
Great to meet you and your wife!
Cool to see you’re working for Horizons! They have some great corporate class ETFs
It is early days like this that makes me glad I can wear scrubs to work...it feels like pyjamas all day
